awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: C-HetNet -Towards Spectrum and Energy Efficient Next Generation Wireless Access Networks
awd_abstract_narration:
The objective of this research is to exploit and establish the theoretical foundations to support the design of next generation cooperative, clean and centralized heterogeneous wireless access networks, or, C-HetNet. The approaches include designing novel algorithms for spectrum efficiency, energy efficiency and quality of service based mobile association, multi-layer interference management and power control, network wide cooperation and dynamic resource allocation in the C-HetNet; and seeking the design principles of balancing and optimizing spectrum efficiency, energy efficiency and quality of service in the C-HetNet.

Intellectual merit: 

The project is expected to significantly advance the understanding in the heterogeneous wireless networks, which are expected to play a key role in meeting the future data capacity explosion and energy consumption escalation. The project will address the unique technical challenges in the C-HetNet and explore new solutions to spectrum and energy efficiency in mobile association, multi-layer interference management and power control, and dynamic cooperative resource allocation. 

Broader Impacts: 

The C-HetNet research activities have significant potentials to revolutionize wireless access networking technologies and wireless cross-layer design approaches. The research will provide a new wireless network paradigm to meet the ever-increasing wireless traffic demand and to address the needs on network cost reduction and global environmental protection; and will improve many application scenarios such as coverage extension, hotspots, and emergency network deployment for public safety, disaster rescues and medical applications. The research outcomes will be disseminated through publications and seminars and will be incorporated into undergraduate and graduate courses taught by the PIs.

por.por_cntn:
This project investigated the fundamental design principles and exploited the theoretical foundations for the next generation cooperative, clean and centralized heterogeneous wireless access networks, or simply, C-HetNet. The proposed C-HetNet research aims at balancing and optimizing spectrum efficiency (SE), energy efficiency (EE) as well as QoS. The approaches included identifying and addressing the new technical challenges and new research opportunities in the C-HetNet framework; designing novel algorithms for SE, EE and QoS based mobile association, multi-layer interference management and power control, network wide cooperation and dynamic resource allocation in the C-HetNet; and studying the performance tradeoff among SE, EE and QoS under various scenarios.

The project can provide a new wireless network paradigm to meet the ever increasing wireless traffic volume demand and also to address the needs on network cost reduction and global environmental protection. The new network paradigm can also improve many application scenarios such as rural area coverage extension, urban hotspots, coverage holes, indoor hotspots, group mobility and emergency and temporary network deployment for public safety, disaster rescues and medical applications.

During the four years of the project, the project team explored two of the most challenging requirements for design and deployment of C-HetNet, multi-layer interference management and power control, and dynamic cooperative resource allocation, by providing detailed novel algorithm designs for SE, EE and QoS, and then studying C-HetNet  theoretical limits and performance tradeoffs. Specifically, various research activities were conducted:

-   Mobile association with SE, EE and QoS in C-HetNet

-   Mobile association with SE and QoS

-   Mobile association with EE consideration

-   Multi-layer interference management and power control in C-HetNet

-   Separate mobile association and interference management

-   Joint interference management and mobile association

-   Interference management and mobile association in a L-layer C-HetNet

-   Cooperative radio resource allocation in C-HetNet

-   Dynamic resource allocation with 2-node cooperation

-   Optimal cooperative size N and cooperation overhead study

Computer simulations and a prototype testbed were developed to evaluate the performance and tradeoffs and validate the theoretical results for C-HetNet. As part of the comprehensive study, theoretical results to achieve optimal performance for C-HetNet, as well as practical engineering design rules and guidelines for implementation and deployment of C-HetNet, were obtained in the series of studies above.

The C-HetNet research activities have significantly revolutionized wireless access networking technologies and wireless cross-layer design approaches. The project will provide a new wireless network paradigm to meet the ever increasing wireless traffic volume demand and also to address the needs on network cost reduction and global environmental protection. The new network paradigm will also improve many application scenarios such as rural area coverage extension, urban hotspots, coverage holes, indoor hotspots, group mobility and emergency and temporary network deployment for public safety, disaster rescues and medical applications.
